div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: SCENE : GERALD ’ S rooms in Grafton Street . A man ’ s room , pleasantly furnished , with very comfortable arm-chairs , and prints on the walls . Books are lying about , and smoking utensils .
CHARLES , GERALD HALSTANE ’ S servant , opens the door . MR. WRIGHT comes in , a dapper young man , smartly dressed .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: There , you can see for yourself that Mr. Halstane is not at home .

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: Very well , I ’ ll wait for him .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You ’ ll have to wait till midnight , because I don ’ t expect him in .

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: Last time I came you said he ’ d be back in half an hour , and when I returned you said he ’ d just gone out . You don ’ t catch me napping a second time .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: The governor don ’ t take impertinence lying down , Mr. Wright , and he ’ ll look upon it as a great liberty your dunning him in this way .

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: I don ’ t know about taking impertinence , but he ’ ll have to take a summons if my account is not settled at once .

div.stage: There is a ring at the bell .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Ironically .Make yourself quite at home , won ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: Thank you . I will .

div.stage: CHARLES goes out and leaves the door open so that the conversation with RIXON , the solicitor , is heard .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: Outside .Is Mr. Halstane in ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: No , sir . He ’ s gone to his club .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: Well , I ’ ll ring him up . I must see him on a matter of the very greatest importance . You ’ re on the telephone , aren ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Yes , sir . But there ’ s a person waiting to see him .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: Coming in .Oh , never mind .

div.stage: RIXON is a short , rubicund man , with white whiskers and a hearty manner .

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: Going towards him .Mr. Rixon .RIXON looks at him without recognising him .Don ’ t you remember me , sir ? I ’ m the junior partner in Andrews and Wright .

lg.l: Of course I do . I saw your father on business the other day .
Where ’ s the telephone book ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I ’ ll just go and fetch it , sir . Mr. Halstane lent it to the gentleman upstairs .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: Be as quick as you can .

div.stage: CHARLES goes out .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: To MR. WRIGHT .What are you doing here ?

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: Well , the fact is , we ’ ve got a very large account with Halstane , and I ’ m told he ’ s in queer street . I want to get the money before the crash comes .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: Queer street ? The man ’ s just come into seven thousand a year .

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: That ’ s why I ’ m running all over the place to find him . You know he ’ s a relation of the Hollingtons . I was at her ladyship ’ s not half an hour ago — the Dowager , you know — my firm has acted for the whole family for the last hundred years . Well , I ’ d hardly arrived before a message came from the War Office to say that her grandson , the present lord , had been killed in India . So as soon as I could , I bolted round here . Mr. Halstane is the next heir , and he comes into seven thousand a year and the title .

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: My gracious , that ’ s a piece of luck .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: I don ’ t mind telling you now that he ’ d pretty well come to the end of his tether . Your money was all right because he ’ d have paid everything up , but he wouldn ’ t have had much left .

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: Of course he doesn ’ t know anything about this yet ?

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: Not a word . For all he knows , he ’ s a ruined man , and here am I trying to get him on the telephone to tell him he ’ s come into a peerage and a very handsome income .

div.stage: CHARLES enters with the telephone book .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: 7869 Gerrard , sir .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: Thanks .

div.stage: He rings up and asks for the number .

sp.speaker: RIXON
sp.p: 7869 Gerrard , please , Miss .... What ? Confound it , the line ’ s engaged .... I must go round to his club in a cab . I suppose you don ’ t want to wait here now , Wright ?

sp.speaker: MR. WRIGHT
sp.p: No , sir . I ’ ll get back to the shop .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I ’ ope you ’ ll suit your own convenience , sir .CHARLES shows them out and comes back .I don ’ t know what these tradespeople are coming to when they expect gentlemen to pay their bills .

div.stage: He seats himself in the most comfortable chair in the room and puts his feet on the table . His back is to the door . The newspaper is lying by his side . He shuts his eyes and dozes .
GERALD enters silently , followed immediately by BLENKINSOP and FREDDIE PERKINS .

GERALD is a handsome man of seven or eight and twenty , simple in his manners , carefully dressed but without exaggeration . FREDDIE is a vivacious boy of two and twenty , BLENKINSOP is an old bachelor of five and forty ; he is well-preserved and takes a good deal of care of his appearance . He is dressed in the height of fashion .
For a moment they look silently at CHARLES , who wakes with a start and jumps up in confusion .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I beg your pardon , sir ; I didn ’ t hear you come in .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: With an ironical politeness which he preserves during all his remarks to CHARLES .Pray don ’ t let us disturb you . I shall never forgive myself if I think I ’ ve interrupted your nap .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Shall I take your hat , sir ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you . I shouldn ’ t like you to put yourself out .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Sitting down .By Jove , what a ripping chair ! No wonder that Charles went to sleep .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Mr. Rixon has just been , sir . He ’ s gone on to the club .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: With a laugh .I ’ m not sorry to miss him . One ’ s solicitor seldom has any good news to bring one .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Will you have the whiskey and soda , sir ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: If it wouldn ’ t give you too much trouble .

div.stage: CHARLES goes out , and GERALD hands the cigarette box to BLENKINSOP and FREDDIE .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Sit down and make yourself comfortable , James .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: To do that is one of the few principles I ’ ve adhered to in the course of an easy and unadventurous life .

div.stage: CHARLES enters with a tray on which are glasses , whiskey and sodas .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Is there anything else you want , sir ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: If you can spare me two minutes of your valuable time , I should like to make a few observations to you .

lg.l: Collect yourself , Charles , to receive the words of wisdom that fall from
Mr. Halstane ’ s lips .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Things is very bad on the Stock Exchange , sir .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Charles , I have no objection to your sitting in my arm-chair and putting your feet on my table . I am willing to ignore the fact that you smoke my cigars and drink my whiskey .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Sipping .You show excellent judgment , Charles . The whiskey ’ s capital .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Imperturbably .Pot-still , sir . Fifteen years in bottle .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I can even bear with equanimity that you should read my letters . For the most part they ’ re excessively tedious , and they will only show you how deplorable is the education of the upper classes . But I must insist on your not reading my paper till I ’ ve done with it .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry , sir . I thought there was no objection .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: A newspaper , a suit of clothes , and a bottle of wine are three things at which I prefer ....

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: To ’ ave the first cut in , sir .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I thank you , Charles ; I couldn ’ t have expressed my meaning more idiomatically .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Laughing .You ’ d better have a drink .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Allow me , sir .

div.stage: He mixes a whiskey and soda .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You need not pour out the whiskey with such a generous hand as when you help yourself . Thank you .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Them mining shares of yours is very low , sir .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: They are .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: If you ’ ll remember , sir , I was all against them at the time you bought .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You are a jewel , Charles , if besides administering to your master ’ s wants you advise him in his financial transactions .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Unless I ’ m mistaken , Charles strongly recommended me to invest my money in public-houses .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Them being frequented in peace and war , and not subject to clandestine removals . In peace men drink to celebrate their ’ appiness , and in war to drown their sorrow .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Smiling .You are a philosopher , Charles , and it cuts me to the quick that I should be forced to deny myself the charm of your conversation .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Astonished .I beg your pardon , sir ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I am endeavouring to give you notice in such a manner as not to outrage your susceptibilities .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Me , sir ? I ’ m sorry if I don ’ t give satisfaction .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: On the contrary , you give every satisfaction . It has never been my good fortune to run across a servant who had an equal talent for blacking boots and for repartee . I am grateful for the care with which you have kept my wardrobe , and the encouragement you have offered to my attempts at humour . I have never seen you perturbed by a rebuke , or discouraged by ill-temper . Your merits , in fact , are overwhelming , but I ’ m afraid I must ask you to find another place .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You really shouldn ’ t be so abrupt , Gerald . Look at him staggering under the blow .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I ’ m very comfortable here , sir . Can you give me no reason for this decision ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You gave it yourself , Charles . As you justly observed , them mining shares is very low . You are sufficiently acquainted with my correspondence to be aware that my creditors have passed with singular unanimity from the stage of remonstrance to that of indignation .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I say , I ’ m sorry to hear this , old man .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: If it ’ s just a matter of wages , sir , I shall be ’ appy to wait till it suits your convenience to pay me .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: With a smile of thanks .I ’ m grateful to you for that , Charles ; but , honestly , do you think half-measures can be of any use to me ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , sir , so far as I ’ m acquainted with your circumstances ....

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Come , come , this modesty ill becomes you . Is there a bill in this room , or a solicitor ’ s letter , with which you are not intimately acquainted ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , sir , if you ask me outright — things is pretty bad .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I say , don ’ t play the ass any more . What the deuce does it all mean ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m sorry the manner in which I ’ m imparting to you an interesting piece of information , doesn ’ t meet with your approval . Would you like me to tear my hair in handfuls ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It would be picturesque , but painful .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Are you really broke ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: So much so that I ’ ve to-day sublet my rooms . In a week , Charles , I shall cast the dust of London off my feet , a victim to the British custom of primogeniture .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Have you the least idea what I mean ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: No , sir .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , I feel certain that during some of the many leisure moments you have enjoyed in my service , you have cast an eye upon that page in Burke upon which my name figures — insignificantly .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Begging your pardon , sir , I looked you up in the Peerage before I accepted the situation .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It rejoices me to learn that your investigations were satisfactory .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well , sir , always having lived before with titled gentlemen , I felt I owed it to myself to be careful .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I am overpowered by your condescension , Charles . It never occurred to me that you were taking my character while I was taking yours .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: If servants wanted as good characters from masters as masters want from servants , I ’ ave an idea that many gentlemen would ’ ave to clean their own boots .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You scintillate , Charles , but I deplore your tendency to digress .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I beg pardon , sir . As you was the second son of an honourable and very well connected , I didn ’ t mind stretching a point . If I may say so , your father was almost a nobleman .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: The consequence is , however , that I was brought up without in the least knowing how to earn my living . I belong to that vast army of younger sons whose sole means of livelihood is a connection with a peer of the realm and such mother-wit as Dame Nature has provided them with .

div.stage: A ring is heard .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: There ’ s some one at the door , sir . Are you at home ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No , I expect two ladies to tea in half an hour , but you must admit no one else . These gentlemen will be forced to deprive me of their society in twenty-five minutes .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not at all . Not at all .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I repeat with considerable firmness that these gentlemen will be compelled by a previous engagement to leave me in twenty minutes .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It ’ ll be difficult after that to make our departure seem perfectly natural , won ’ t it ?

div.stage: A second ring is heard .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Nobody ’ s to come in .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: He goes out .

lg.l: I say , old man , I ’ m awfully sorry to hear this bad news of yours . Can ’ t
I do anything to help you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No , thanks .

div.stage: The bell is rung continuously , with the greatest impatience .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: By Jove , whoever your visitor is , he doesn ’ t like being kept waiting .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Outside .Is Mr. Halstane at home ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Softly .Why , it ’ s my aunt .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Mrs . Dot .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Ssh !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Not at home , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Outside .Nonsense . I want to see him very particularly .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I ’ m very sorry , madam . Mr. Halstane went out not five minutes ago . I almost wonder you didn ’ t meet him on the stairs .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Yes , I know all about that .

div.stage: MRS. WORTHLEY comes in . She is a pretty little woman , very wonderfully gowned . She is frank , open and full of spirits . CHARLES follows her into the room .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh ! Three of you . Charles , how can you tell such stories ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Very gravely .Mr. Halstane is not at home , madam .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Coming forward and taking her hand .Charles is shocked at your lack of decorum .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Run away , Charles . And don ’ t do it again .... I suppose you think this sort of thing isn ’ t done in the best families ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Stiffly .No , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I saw one of my drays outside , so I thought I ’ d just look in to see how you liked it .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Icily .I beg your pardon , madam ?

lg.l: The beer , my good man , the beer ! Don ’ t you know that I ’ m Worthley ’ s
Entire ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I never gave the subject a thought , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And very good our half-crown family ale is , although I say it as shouldn ’ t .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You may go , Charles .

div.stage: Without a word , much on his dignity CHARLES departs .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Gaily .It ’ s fortunate I ’ ve just given him notice , because Charles would certainly never stay in a house where he ’ d been so grossly insulted .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I love shocking Charles . He ’ s so genteel . Whenever I come here I see him obviously trying not to show that he ’ s perfectly well aware that I have anything to do with trade .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: The world is so degenerate that it ’ s only among domestic servants that you find any respect for landed gentry and any contempt for commerce .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: To FREDDIE .I ’ m glad to see that you ’ re not ruining your health by working too hard as my secretary .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ ve been lunching with Blenkinsop . I answered about fifty begging letters before I came out this morning .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: To GERALD .You ’ ve not said you ’ re glad to see me yet .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m not sure that I am , very .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Not at all disconcerted .Then say you like my frock .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , it ’ s very nice .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Very nice ! I should think it was very nice . There ’ s no one in London who ’ d venture to wear anything half so outrageous . And as for the hat ....

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: The hat ’ s hideous . But I suppose it ’ s fashionable .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear James , where were you educated ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: At Eton .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , they taught you nothing about clothes .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I wish sometimes that nice women wouldn ’ t get themselves up as if they were no better than they should be .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Don ’ t be so absurd . The ideal of a woman who takes any pains about her frocks is to look as like an abandoned hussy as she possibly can .

div.stage: MRS . DOT chooses the most comfortable chair in the room .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I can ’ t ask you to sit down .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t trouble . I ’ m perfectly capable of doing that of my own accord .... If you think I ’ m going before you ’ ve answered a hundred and fifty questions you ’ re very much mistaken . First , I want to know why you ’ ve not been near me for the last week ? Then why you try to keep me out of the place ? And lastly , why you show every desire to get rid of me when I ’ m here ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ ve not seen you because I ’ ve been uncommonly busy . I said I was not at home because I ’ m in the worst possible temper . And I want to get rid of you because I ’ m expecting somebody else .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I suppose if I were a thoroughly tactful person I should now ring for my carriage ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I daresay you would ask me to ring for it .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , I shall neither do the one nor the other . In the first place your answers are all nonsense and in the second I want to know who ’ s coming ? If it ’ s some one I know , I shall stop and say , How d ’ you do , and if it isn ’ t I want to see what it ’ s like .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I suppose you know I ’ m perfectly capable of turning you out by main force .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: If you touch me I shall scream .

div.stage: She looks quickly at FREDDIE and BLENKINSOP , then gives a smile .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , Freddie , I quite forgot . I ’ ve got a pile of letters that I found on my way out this afternoon . There are three poor clergymen who can ’ t pay their bills , and there are five elderly spinsters who don ’ t know which way to turn for their quarter ’ s rent , and there are seven deserving ladies with a starving husband each and sixteen children .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: How very immoral !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It would be much more immoral if they had a starving child each and sixteen husbands .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I suppose it ’ s never occurred to you that you do a great deal more harm than good by your indiscriminate charity ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Don ’ t be such an old frump . If it gives me a certain amount of pleasure to give money away , why on earth shouldn ’ t I ? I daresay that nineteen out of every twenty people I help are thoroughly worthless , but it ’ s only by doing something for them all that I can be quite certain of not missing the twentieth .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: D ’ you want me to write to them at once ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: This very minute .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: With a smile .But that ’ ll only get rid of me , you know . Blenkinsop will still be here .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Coolly .James , do go and see that Freddie writes his letters nicely . He ’ s only just come down from Oxford , and his spelling is rather shaky .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: With a grunt .You can give us a shout when you ’ ve had your talk .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now mind , Freddie . I before E except after C .

div.stage: They go out .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Laughing .You ’ re a very bold woman , Mrs . Dot .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With a change of tone .What ’ s the matter , Gerald ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Surprised .With me ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Won ’ t you tell an old friend ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: After a very short pause .Nothing that you can help me in , Mrs . Dot .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Won ’ t you leave the Mrs. out ? It makes me feel so five and thirtyish .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You ’ re a ripping good sort , and we ’ ve had some charming times together . I ’ m glad that you came to-day , because it ’ s given me an opportunity to thank you for all your kindness to me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear boy , what are you talking about ?

lg.l: Well , the fact is , I ’ ve been spending a good deal of money lately , and
I ’ m rather broke .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: How stupid of me ! I ’ ve always had such lots myself it never occurs to me that any one else may be hard up . And I ’ ve let you pay all sorts of things for me , theatres and dinners and heaven knows what . I must owe you a perfect fortune .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Nonsense ! You don ’ t owe me a penny .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well then , in future I insist on paying for everything . I ’ m not going to give up our little dinners at the Savoy and our suppers and all the rest of it . Don ’ t be so silly . You know I have ten times more money than I know what to do with .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , I can see you furtively slipping your purse into my hand so that I should pay for a luncheon , and giving me a shilling over for the cab . No , thank you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Then we ’ ll economise together . It only means going to the pit of a theatre instead of taking a box . Well , I like the pit much better . You see all the women come in and you criticise their back hair . And you suck delicious oranges all the time . It makes my mouth water to think of it . And we ’ ll go on a bus instead of taking cabs . They ’ re much safer , and I like sitting on the front seat and talking to the driver . Bus-drivers are always such handsome men .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s not a question of driving in buses , but of walking on my flat feet .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Very well . You shall walk on your flat feet , and I ’ ll trip along by your side on my arched instep .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Things have come to such a pass that I must either beg , steal , or work .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Then tell me exactly how matters stand .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It would only bore you , and besides you wouldn ’ t understand .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now you ’ re talking through your hat , my friend . You ’ re simply talking through your hat . I flatter myself there are few men who have a better head for business than I have . Why , since my husband died I ’ ve almost doubled our profits . The brewery has never been so flourishing . I ’ ve told the British People on fifty thousand hoardings to drink Worthley ’ s Half-crown Family Ale , and by Jove , the British People do .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You funny little thing .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , now tell me all about it , and let ’ s see if things can ’ t be put straight .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , my dear , I ’ m afraid they ’ re in a most awful mess . I never had much money to start with , and I got into debt . Then I tried a flutter on the Stock Exchange , and the confounded shares went down steadily from the day I bought .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It ’ s a way shares have when fools buy them .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: But I daresay I could have weathered that , only a pal of mine got into a hole , and I backed a bill for him .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say you did that ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I was obliged to . I couldn ’ t let him go under without trying to do something .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You donkey , you perfect donkey !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: He swore he ’ d be able to pay the money .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I never knew a man yet , or a woman either for that matter , who ’ d stick at a thundering lie when he wanted money . And what ’ s the result ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , the result is that after I ’ ve paid everything up , I shall have about five hundred pounds left . I ’ m proposing to go out to America and rough it a bit .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Pardon my asking , but do you think a handsome face , a talent for small talk , and a certain charm of manner will enable you to earn your daily bread ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Laughing .I don ’ t want to seem vain , but although I ’ ve done my best to conceal them , I fancy I have two or three other qualifications which will be of more service .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Then the long and the short of it is that you ’ re ruined .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Absolutely .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m delighted to hear it .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Dot !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I am . I can ’ t help it . But I think your plan of going to the States is simply foolish .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What else can I do ? The Cape ’ s entirely played out .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You stupid creature .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I beg your pardon !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You belong to a class whose chief resource when it has squandered its money is a rich marriage . The custom is so well recognised that when a man of good family emigrates rather than have recourse to it , society is outraged and suspicious .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Thanks . I don ’ t think I can see myself marrying for money .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Don ’ t be so absurd . I never heard that the course of true love ran any less smoothly because a charming widow had sixty thousand a year .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear boy , I ’ m not a perfect fool . A man thinks a woman never sees anything unless she looks at it with both eyes at once wide open . Don ’ t you know that she can see things through the back of her head with a stone wall in between ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What have you seen , then ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ ve seen a thousand things . I ’ ve seen your eyes light up when I came into the room , I ’ ve seen you watch me when you thought I wasn ’ t looking . I ’ ve seen you scowl at any young fool who paid me an outrageous compliment . I ’ ve seen the pleasure it gave you to do me any trifling service . I ’ ve seen you watch for the opportunity of putting my cloak on my shoulders after the play . And — I ’ m sorry — but I ’ ve come to the conclusion that you ’ re in love with me . I dare say the fact has escaped your notice , but that ’ s only because men are so deplorably stupid .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Gravely .D ’ you think it ’ s quite kind to laugh at me now ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But I ’ m not laughing at you , my dear . I ’ m so pleased , and so flattered and so touched . At first I thought I was only a fool , and that I saw those things only because I wanted to . And when your hand trembled a little as it took mine , I was afraid it was only my hand that was trembling . And at last when I was certain that you were just as much in love with me as I was with you , I was so glad that I cried for two hours . And I had to use a whole box of powder before I could make myself presentable again .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Grimly .I ’ m afraid you ’ ll think me an utter brute . I ought to have told you long ago that I ’ m engaged to be married .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Gerald !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ ve been engaged to Nellie Sellenger for the last three years .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Why didn ’ t you tell me ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No one was supposed to know anything about it . And — I was afraid of losing you . Oh , Dot , Dot , I love you with all my heart . And I ’ m so glad to be forced to tell you at last .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But I don ’ t understand in the least .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You know Nellie Sellenger is an old friend of mine .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Yes , it was at the Sellengers ’ I first met you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , three years ago we were staying at the same place in the country , and I was a young fool .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You mean that there was no other girl there , and so you flirted with her . But you need not have asked her to marry you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Apologetically .It was the merest accident . It came to pieces in my ’ ands , so to speak .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: We were taking a walk in the garden after dinner , and a perfectly absurd moon was shining . It seemed the obvious thing to do .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And of course she accepted . The girl of eighteen always does .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: But Lady Sellenger refused to hear of it . She thought me most ineligible .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Lady Sellenger ’ s a sensible woman . She was quite right .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m not so sure . If she ’ d given us her blessing and told us to do as we liked , we should probably have broken it off in three weeks . But she was really rather offensive about it . She refused to let Nellie see me , and the result was that we were always running across one another in Bond Street tea-shops .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Monstrous ! And so bad for the digestion .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Some time ago Lady Sellenger found out that we were writing to one another and so on , so she came to see me and said she ’ d made up her mind to take Nellie abroad for a year . She made me promise to hold no communication with her during that time , and agreed that if we were still of the same mind when they came back , she would withdraw the opposition and let us be properly engaged .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: An announcement in the Morning Post and all that sort of thing ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I suppose so .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And when are they coming back ?

lg.l: They came back last week . But I haven ’ t had a chance of speaking to
Nellie yet . The year is up to-day , and this morning I had a note from
Lady Sellenger asking if they might come to tea .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And what are you going to say to her ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Good heavens ! What can I say ? I was poor enough a year ago , but now I ’ m penniless . I ’ m bound to ask for my release .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Then why on earth have you been trying to make me utterly miserable ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You know , I don ’ t want to seem an awful prig , but I don ’ t think I should much like doing anything shabby . If Nellie wants me to keep my promise I shan ’ t draw back .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , but she won ’ t . She ’ ll be only too glad to get rid of you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid there ’ s something else I must tell you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: More ? Don ’ t say you ’ ve got a horrible past , because I shan ’ t turn a hair .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No , it ’ s not that . You know that Lord Hollington is a relation of mine .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Only a fifteenth cousin , isn ’ t he ? Far too distant to brag about .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: A year ago three lives stood between me and the peerage . It seemed impossible that I could ever come into anything .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: But last winter my cousin George unfortunately broke his neck in the hunting-field , and his poor old father died of the shock . If anything happened to my cousin Charles everything would come to me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And Lady Sellenger would doubtless withdraw her opposition to your marriage .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: She ’ s a very nice woman , but she has rather a keen eye for the main chance .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Even her best friend would hesitate to call her disinterested . But why should anything happen to Lord Hollington ? He ’ s quite young , isn ’ t he ? I saw his engagement announced in the Morning Post a little while ago .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: He ’ s out in India at this moment . He ’ s a soldier , you know . It appears there ’ s some trouble on the North-West Frontier , and he ’ s in command of the expedition .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , but nothing is going to happen to him . He ’ ll live till he ’ s eighty .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m sure I hope he will .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Say again that you love me , Gerald .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Smiling .I oughtn ’ t to yet .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You know , you ’ ve got to marry me . I insist upon it . After all , you ’ ve been trifling with my affections shamefully . Oh , we shall be so happy , Gerald . And we ’ ll never grow any older than we are now . You know , I ’ m an awfully good sort , really . I talk a lot of nonsense , but I don ’ t mean it . I very seldom listen to it myself . I ’ m sick of society . I want to settle down and be domesticated . I ’ ll sit at home and darn your socks . And I shall hate it , and I shall be so happy . And if you want to be independent you can have a job at the brewery . We want a smart energetic man to keep us up to the times . And we ’ ll have a lovely box at the opera , and you can always get away for the shooting .

div.stage: A ring is heard .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: There they are .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Good heavens ! I quite forgot about those wretched people in there .

div.stage: She opens the door of the dining-room .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I don ’ t want to disturb you , but if you ’ ve quite finished your conversation perhaps you ’ d like to come and have tea .

div.stage: BLENKINSOP and FREDDIE come in and go to the fire .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I observe with interest that your remark is facetious .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ m simply freezing .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You didn ’ t mind being shut up in there , did you ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not at all . I rather like sitting in an arctic room without a fire , with a window looking on a blank wall , and the society of your nephew and the Sporting Times of the week before last as my only means of entertainment .

div.stage: CHARLES enters to announce the SELLENGERS . He goes out and brings in the tea .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Lady and Miss Sellenger .

div.stage: Enter LADY SELLENGER and NELLIE . LADY SELLENGER is a pompous woman of fifty , stout , alert and clever . NELLIE is very pretty and graceful , and fashionably gowned . She appears to be much under her mother ’ s influence .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: How d ’ you do ? Ah , Mrs. Worthley ! Delightful !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Shaking hands .How d ’ you do ? I think you know Mr. Blenkinsop ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Of course . But I don ’ t approve of him .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Because you ’ re a cynic , a millionaire , and a bachelor . And no man has the right to be all three .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And how did you like Italy ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: A grossly over-rated place . So many marriageable daughters and so few eligible men .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Introducing .Mr. Perkins , Lady Sellenger — Miss Sellenger .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My nephew and my secretary .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Really . How very interesting ! Almost romantic .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Worthley , what a charming gown ! You always wear such — striking things .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It advertises the beer , don ’ t you know .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I wish I could drink it , Mrs. Worthley , but it ’ s so fattening . I understand you always have it on your table .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I think that ’ s the least I can do , as it ’ s only on account of the beer that I can have a table at all .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: To MRS . DOT .May I give you some tea ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Going to the tea-table .Thanks so much .

div.stage: GERALD comes over to LADY SELLENGER with a cup . She takes it . The others are gathered round the tea-table , which is right at the back , and talk among themselves .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Come and sit by me , Gerald . I ’ ve not had a word with you since we came back from Italy .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Lightly .What are you going to say to me ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: You can guess why I wrote to ask if we might come and see you to-day ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Rising .Yes .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Now do sit down . And look as if you were talking of the weather .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s a little difficult to discuss the matter quite indifferently .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: My dear boy , it ’ s the little difficulties of life which prevent it from being dull . We should be no better than the beasts of the field if we had no anxieties about our soul and our position in society .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I see .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Rather impatiently .My dear Gerald , why don ’ t you help me ? What I have to say is so very unpleasant . You know I have always had a most sincere affection for you . Under other circumstances I would have wanted no better son-in-law .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s very kind of you to say so .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I ’ ve assured you for the last three years that a marriage was absurd , and now I want to tell you that it ’ s impossible . Love is all very well in its way , but it doesn ’ t make up for a shabby house in the suburbs .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You ’ re not romantic , Lady Sellenger .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: My dear , when you reach my age you ’ ll agree with me that it ’ s only the matter of fact which really signifies . Love in a cottage is a delusion of youth . It ’ s difficult enough after ten years of solid matrimony in Grosvenor Square .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You married for love , Lady Sellenger .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I ’ m anxious that my daughter shouldn ’ t make the same mistake . Now let us be quite frank with one another .... Are you sure they ’ re not listening ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Glancing at the others .They seem very much occupied with their own affairs . What is your ultimatum ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Well , Gerald , I ’ m not in the least mercenary . I know that money can ’ t give happiness . But I do feel that unless you have at least two thousand a year you can ’ t make my daughter even comfortable .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m sure that ’ s very modest .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: It ’ s not love in a cottage . It ’ s not love in a palace . It ’ s just — matrimony in Onslow Gardens .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I may as well tell you at once that I ’ ve had very bad luck . I wanted to make money , and I ’ ve come an absolute cropper .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: My dear Gerald , I ’ m very sorry . Is it as bad as all that ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It couldn ’ t be much worse .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Dear me , that ’ s very sad . But , of course , it simplifies matters , doesn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Enormously . It puts marriage entirely out of the question and leaves only one course open to me . I ’ ll take the earliest opportunity to ask Nellie for my release .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: What a pity it is you ’ re so poor ! Your principles are really excellent .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: But what about Nellie ? How will she take it ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: She ’ s so reserved , poor dear ! She never speaks of her feelings . But after three London seasons most girls have learnt to bow to the inevitable . And how is Lord Hollington ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: He ’ s to be married as soon as he comes back from India .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: It was dreadfully sad that his uncle and his cousin should die within a year . If anything happened to him you ’ d be in very different circumstances . But , of course , it would be wicked to wish it . I hope you never do .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Never . I trust he ’ ll live to a hundred .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: And I daresay he ’ ll have fifteen children . Those delicate men often do .... Why don ’ t you speak to Nellie now and get it over ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: This very minute ? With others in the room ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: That ’ s just it , I want to give neither of you any opportunity for sentiment .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You ’ re certainly very practical .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: No woman can afford to be sentimental when she has a marriageable daughter .... For heaven ’ s sake don ’ t make Nellie cry , we ’ re dining out to-night .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ ll do my best to be very matter of fact .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Raising her voice .Mr. Blenkinsop , I want to quarrel with you !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Coming forward .You fill me with consternation .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: You passed us in Pall Mall this afternoon and you cut us dead .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I ’ m so sorry , I didn ’ t see you . I ’ d just been to the War Office to inquire if there was any news of those fellows out in India . By the way , Halstane , isn ’ t Hollington a relation of yours ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , why ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Haven ’ t you seen anything in the paper ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No .

lg.l: Oh , but surely . There ’ s sure to be something about it in the
Westminster .

div.stage: He takes up the paper .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: That ’ s an early one .

div.stage: Faintly are heard the cries of “ Special .”

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Listen , there ’ s the last edition coming along .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: But what is it , Mr. Blenkinsop ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: A small force was sent out to punish some local people up in the hills , who ’ d been making themselves troublesome , and it hasn ’ t been heard of since . The idea is that there may have been some trouble and they ’ ve all got cut up .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But how does it concern Lord Hollington ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: He was in command of it .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Good God !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: When I was there a couple of hours ago the War Office had no news at all .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: But why didn ’ t you tell me about it ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I thought you knew . I ’ d forgotten for the moment that Hollington had anything to do with you . He ’ s a very distant relation , isn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes , I hardly know him .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: But if anything has happened to him ....

div.stage: Cries outside of “ Special , Special .”

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Why don ’ t you get a paper ? Freddie , run and get one , will you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: No , Charles can go .

div.stage: He rings , and CHARLES immediately comes in .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , Charles , get a paper at once . Hurry up !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: He goes out . Outside , cries of “ Terrible catastrophe in India .”

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: By Jove , did you hear that ?

div.stage: Cries of “ Special , Special .”

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Why doesn ’ t he make haste ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Nonsense . It can ’ t have anything to do with Hollington .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With her hand on his arm , anxiously .Gerald .

div.stage: FREDDIE PERKINS is looking out of the window .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Here ’ s Charles . By Jove , he isn ’ t hurrying himself much .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Has he got a newsboy ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Yes . What the deuce is he doing ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: At the window .Good lord , he ’ s reading the paper .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: The suspense is too awful .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: There ’ s another newsboy running down the street .

div.stage: Cries of “ Special , Special .”

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Thank God , he ’ s coming upstairs at last . I should like to kick him .Cries of “ Terrible catastrophe in India . ’ Eroic death of Lord ’ Ollington .”Good God !They all remain in silence , full of consternation . CHARLES enters with the paper .Hurry up , man ! What the deuce have you been doing ?

div.stage: He snatches the paper from him .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: With dignity .I made all the ’ aste I could , my lord .

div.stage: GERALD stops for a moment from looking up and down the paper , and stares at him .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What the dickens d ’ you mean ?

div.stage: He looks at the paper , reads , and drops it .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Is it true , Gerald ?

div.stage: He looks at her and nods .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Poor chap . And just as he was going to be married .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Shall I bring your hat and coat , my lord ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What on earth are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I thought your lordship would like to go round to the War Office .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Shut up !

div.stage: Exit CHARLES .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: My dear boy , I congratulate you with all my heart .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t remind me of that already .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I can quite understand you ’ re a little upset , but after all he was only a very distant relation of yours .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I don ’ t understand what all this means .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Didn ’ t you hear that fool of a servant ? It was the first thing he thought of .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Gerald succeeds to the peerage !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Wouldn ’ t you like us to leave you alone ? I ’ m sure you want to think things out a bit ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Come , Nellie !

lg.l: I ’ m sorry to turn you out . Good-bye . I had something to say to you ,
Nellie .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: We ’ ve not had a chance of speaking to one another .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Unctuously .It ’ s very fortunate . Now you ’ ll have much pleasanter things to talk about .

div.stage: He stares at her without understanding .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Things are very different now , Gerald . It just came in time , didn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: LADY SELLENGER and NELLIE go out .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Good-bye , old man , I ’ m sorry your cousin has had such an awful death . But after all , we none of us knew him and we do know you . I can ’ t tell you how glad I am that all your difficulties are at an end .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I would give my right hand to bring Hollington back to life again .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Go away , Freddie . I want to talk to Gerald .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Good-bye , old man . I say , what a nice girl Miss Sellenger is !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: FREDDIE goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: The news has come just an hour too soon . It ’ s bound me hand and foot .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: What d ’ you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Nellie accepted me when I was poor and of no account . Now that I ’ m well off I can ’ t go to her and say : I ’ ve changed my mind and don ’ t want to marry you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: What d ’ you mean by being well off ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I believe I shall have six or seven thousand a year .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But you can ’ t live on that . It ’ s absurd .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: With a smile .There are people who live on much less , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Besides , she doesn ’ t care for you in the least . I could see that at a glance .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: A girl who loved you wouldn ’ t have a skirt cut like that .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I can ’ t draw back now , Dot . You must see that I can ’ t .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: If you cared for me , you ’ d easily find some way out of the difficulty .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I must be honest , Dot .... I don ’ t want to seem a snob , but I ’ ve got an ancient name , and it ’ s rather honourable . I ’ m by way of being the head of the family now . I don ’ t want to begin by acting like a cad .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You know , I ’ m much nicer than Nellie . I ’ m more amusing , and I ’ m better dressed , and I ’ ve got five motor cars . It ’ s true she ’ s younger than I am , but I don ’ t feel a day more than seventeen .With a little look at him .And if you had any sense of decency at all you ’ d say I looked it . You said you loved me just now . Say it again , Gerald . It ’ s so good to hear .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I don ’ t see how we can help ourselves .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Beginning to lose her temper .I suppose you just want to finish an awkward scene ? I don ’ t want to harrow you . Why don ’ t you go to the War Office ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You must see it ’ s not my fault . If we must part , let us part friends .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now , I declare he wants to sentimentalise . Isn ’ t it enough that you ’ ve made me frightfully unhappy ? D ’ you want me to say it doesn ’ t matter at all , as if you ’ d spilt a cup of tea on me ? D ’ you think I like being utterly wretched ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: For heaven ’ s sake , don ’ t talk like that . You ’ re tearing my heart to pieces .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Your heart ? I should like to bang it on the floor and stamp on it . You must expect to suffer a little . You can ’ t put it all on me .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I don ’ t want you to suffer .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: In a temper .You were willing enough to marry me when you hadn ’ t got sixpence to bless yourself with . How fortunate your cousin didn ’ t die a week later !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Do you think I was proposing to marry you for your money ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No , of course not .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Thanks .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , you needn ’ t take it as a compliment . I ’ d much sooner have to deal with a clever knave than an honest fool .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Won ’ t you say that you bear me no ill-will ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I really must go to the War Office .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Very well , you can go .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Won ’ t you come with me ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid you ’ ll get rather bored here .

div.stage: He rings the bell , and CHARLES comes in .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Yes , my lord .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I want my hat and coat .

div.stage: CHARLES goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Do you care for Nellie Sellenger ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: If you don ’ t mind , I won ’ t answer that question . Unless she asks for her freedom , I propose to marry her .

div.stage: CHARLES brings in the hat and coat . MRS . DOT watches him while he puts them on .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: He goes out . MRS . DOT turns round and faces CHARLES .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Charles , have you ever been married ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Twice , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And has experience taught you that when a woman wants a thing she generally gets it ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: With a sigh .It has , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: That is my opinion , too , Charles .She goes out . CHARLES begins to clear the tea things away .END OF THE FIRST ACT

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The terrace of MRS. DOT ’ S house on the River . There are masses of rose trees in full flower . At the back is the house , covered with creepers .
A table is set out for luncheon , with four chairs .
MISS MACGREGOR is sitting in a garden chair , sewing . She is an elderly , quiet woman , thin , somewhat angular , good-humoured and amiable .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT is walking up and down impatiently
sp.p: AUNT ELIZA . My dear , why don ’ t you sit down and rest yourself ? I ’ m sure you ’ ve walked at least ten miles up and down this terrace .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m in a temper .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: That must be obvious to the meanest intelligence .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Have you read the paper to-day ?

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: I ’ ve tried to , but as you ’ ve spent most of the morning in stamping on it , I haven ’ t had much success .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Then I beg you to listen to this :Taking up a “ Morning Post ” and reading it .A marriage has been arranged between Lord Hollington and Eleanor , only daughter of the late General Sir Robert Sellenger .

div.stage: She crumples up the paper and stamps on it .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: That ’ s the twenty-third time you ’ ve read this announcement to me . I assure you that it ’ s beginning to lose its novelty .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You can ’ t deny that it ’ s rather annoying to take up your paper in the morning and discover an official announcement that the man you ’ ve made up your mind to marry is taking serious steps to marry somebody else .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: But would you tell me why you want to marry him ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Why does anybody ever want to marry anybody ?

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: That is a question to which during the fifty-five years of my life I ’ ve been totally unable to discover an answer .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , because he ’ s clever , and handsome , and amusing .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: He ’ s not really very clever , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Of course he isn ’ t . He ’ s as stupid as an owl . I ’ ve told him so till I ’ m blue in the face .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: And he ’ s not really very good-looking , is he ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: On the contrary , I think he ’ s rather plain .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: I suppose you find him amusing ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Not at all . I find him dull .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Then , perhaps , you can find me some other explanation .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , I ’ m head over ears in love with him .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: But why , my dear ? Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Because I am . That ’ s the most conclusive reason possible . And I ’ ve set my heart on marrying him . And the more obstacles there are the more I mean to marry him .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: I can ’ t imagine why you hadn ’ t the sense to fall in love with one of the various eligible persons who want to marry you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But he does want to marry me . He ’ s desperately in love with me .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: I should have thought he could find a better way of showing it than by getting engaged to somebody else .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: He ’ s a sentimentalist , like all his sex . Good heavens , what a mess the world would get into if it weren ’ t for the practical common sense of the average women .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: And what do you propose to do ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: That ’ s just it . I don ’ t in the least know . They ’ ll all be here in half an hour , and I haven ’ t the shadow of a scheme . I lie awake all night racking my brains , and I can ’ t think of anything .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Why did you ask them to come here ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I thought I might hit upon something if they were under my eyes . Gerald had promised to spend Whitsun with me and , so that he shouldn ’ t put me off , I asked the Sellengers , too . Lady Sellenger was only too glad to get a week ’ s board and lodging for nothing .The sound is heard of a motor stopping .There ’ s Jimmie Blenkinsop . I told you he was going to motor down in time for luncheon , didn ’ t I ?BLENKINSOP comes in with FREDDIE . FREDDIE has on a gay tweed suit .Jimmie !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: How d ’ you do ?

div.stage: He shakes hands with MRS . DOT and AUNT ELIZA .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now we ’ ll have luncheon . You must be starving with hunger .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You must let me wash first .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No , we ’ re all far too hungry . Freddie will go and wash his hands for you .

div.stage: She rings half a dozen times quickly on a little bell on the table .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I shall be back in one minute .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now sit down . I ’ m perfectly ravenous .

div.stage: THE BUTLER and the FOOTMAN bring in luncheon , which is eaten during the next scene .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: I perceive that the tender passion hasn ’ t in the least interfered with your appetite .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , my dear James , I ’ m so unhappy .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You look it .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: By the way , how do I look ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: All right . You ’ ve changed your cook .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Hang my cook .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t if I were you . She ’ s very good .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Of course you ’ ll drink the family ale ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Of course I ’ ll do nothing of the kind .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You know it ’ s one of my principles to have it on the table .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Yes , but it ’ s one of my principles not to drink it . I seem to remember that you have some particularly fine hock .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Jimmie , have you never been in love ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Never , thank God .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I don ’ t believe it . Every one ’ s in love . I ’ m in love .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not with me , I trust .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You perfect idiot .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not at all . I should think it very natural .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I wonder why you never married , James .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Because I have a considerable gift for repartee . I discovered in my early youth that men propose not because they want to marry , but because on certain occasions they are entirely at a loss for topics of conversation .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Smiling .It was a momentous discovery .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: No sooner had I made it than I began to cultivate my power of small talk . I felt that my only chance was to be ready with appropriate subjects at the shortest notice , and I spent a considerable part of my last year at Oxford in studying the best masters .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I never noticed that you were particularly brilliant .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I never played for brilliancy . I played for safety . I flatter myself that when prattle was needed I have never been found wanting . I have met the ingenuity of sweet seventeen with a few observations on Free Trade , while the haggard efforts of thirty have struggled in vain against a brief exposition of the higher philosophy . The skittish widow of uncertain age has retired in disorder before a complete acquaintance with the restoration dramatists , and I have routed the serious spinster with religious leanings by my remarkable knowledge of the results of missionary endeavour in Central Africa . Once a dowager sought to ask me my intentions , but I flung at her astonished head an entire article from the “ Encyclopædia Britannica .” These are only my serious efforts . I need not tell you how often I have evaded a flash of the eyes by an epigram or ignored a sigh by an apt quotation from the poets .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I don ’ t believe a word you say . I believe you never married for the simple reason that nobody would have you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Do me the justice to acknowledge that I ’ m the only man who ’ s known you ten days without being tempted by your preposterous income to offer you his hand and heart .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I don ’ t believe my income has anything to do with it . I put it down entirely to my very considerable personal attractions .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Here is Freddie , at last . What has he been doing ?

div.stage: FREDDIE comes in , having changed into flannels .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Why on earth have you changed your clothes ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Sitting down at table .I regard it as part of my duties as your secretary to look nice .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I don ’ t know that I think it essential for you to put on seven different suits a day .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I thought Miss Sellenger would probably like to go on the river before tea .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: If she does , it ’ s more likely to be with Lord Hollington than with you .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Oh , that ’ s rot . Gerald ’ s an awfully good sort , but he ’ s not the sort of chap a girl ’ s desperately fond of .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You think that , do you ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Well , you can ’ t see yourself falling in love with him can you ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No . No .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: And what is the sort of man a girl ’ s desperately fond of ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t know .Taking up a spoon and looking at himself , twisting an infinitesimal moustache .I should think some one a bit younger than Gerald .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With a little shriek .You !

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You needn ’ t be so surprised . One might do worse , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: To AUNT ELIZA pointing with a scornful finger at FREDDIE .Do you think any one could possibly fall in love with that ?

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I say , come now . That ’ s a bit thick .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: To BLENKINSOP .If you were a young and lovely maiden would you fall in love with Freddie ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Looking at him doubtfully .Well , if you ask me point blank I don ’ t think I should .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You ’ re all of you jolly supercilious .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: He ’ s not positively plain , is he ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not positively .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Look here , you shut up . I bet I could cut you out with any girl you like to mention .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Rubbish !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I daresay he can whisper nonsense in a woman ’ s ear as well as any one else .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: It ’ s born in them , the brutes .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Pooh ! I wouldn ’ t waste my time on whispering nonsense . I ’ d just send my pass-book round by a messenger boy .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Well , I flatter myself Miss Sellenger will be much more pleased to see me than to see anybody else down here .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You ’ ve only seen her once .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: She ’ s a jolly nice girl , I can tell you that .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Ironically .I suppose she squeezed your hand when you went away ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Well , it so happens , she did .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You needn ’ t be set up about it , because she squeezed mine , too . It ’ s evidently a habit .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Yours ! What rot !

div.stage: MRS . DOT has been staring at him , with both elbows on the table . A servant is standing at her side with a tray on which is the coffee .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Thompson is offering you some coffee , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Absently .Take it away .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: What on earth are you staring at ? Isn ’ t my tie all right ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You certainly are rather good-looking . I ’ ve never noticed it before .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: It ’ s no good , you know . You ’ re my aunt , and the prayer book wouldn ’ t let you marry me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now I come to think of it , I daresay you ’ re quite grown up to any one who didn ’ t know you in Etons .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know what on earth you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I suppose a girl might quite easily fall in love with you . It had never occurred to me .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Which means that you ’ ve found him a wife , and you ’ re going to marry him to some one whether he likes it or not .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Suddenly .Freddie .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Hulloa !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Go away and play .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Hang it all , I want to drink my coffee .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Go and make a mud pie in the garden . There ’ s a dear .

div.stage: A bell is heard ringing loudly .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: There they are !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Come on !

div.stage: They all get up . MRS . DOT and AUNT ELIZA go out . FREDDIE and BLENKINSOP light cigarettes .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: What ’ s the matter with my virtuous aunt ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: How old are you , dear boy ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Twenty-two . Why ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: The delightful age when it ’ s still possible to feel desperately wicked . But you are old enough to have learnt that the moods of women are inscrutable .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Oh , rot ! I never met a woman whom I couldn ’ t read at a glance .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Ironically .Really ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You know , they talk about the incomprehensibility of women , but it ’ s all humbug .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: When you see a blank wall , does it ever occur to you that there ’ s anything on the other side ?

div.stage: MRS . DOT and AUNT ELIZA come in with LADY SELLENGER , NELLIE and HOLLINGTON . They are all talking .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: We had a delightful journey . Oh , how beautiful your garden is ! So romantic . I love romance .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: When it ’ s backed by an adequate income .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: How d ’ you do ? You cynic .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I ’ m nothing of the sort . But I occasionally tell the truth .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: You ’ re the most cynical man in London , and I ’ m frightened to death of you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: There ’ s nothing the world loves more than a ready-made description which they can hang on to a man , and so save themselves all trouble in future . When I was quite young it occurred to some one that I was a cynic , and since then I ’ ve never been able to remark that it was a fine day without being accused of odious cynicism .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: My dear Mr. Blenkinsop , what every one says is always true . That is one of the foundations of society .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I gained my reputation by remarking once that it was possible for a penniless young man who married a very rich woman old enough to be his mother to be genuinely in love with her .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I think it was a very cynical observation .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: To LADY SELLENGER .You know my nephew , don ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: How d ’ you do ? I think we met at dear Gerald ’ s a week or two ago .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Shaking hands .How d ’ you do ?To NELLIE .Have you quite forgotten me ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Not quite !

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Jolly day , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Awfully jolly .

div.stage: MRS . DOT watches them as they shake hands .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: To LADY SELLENGER .Would you like me to show you your rooms ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Thanks , so much .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Freddie , is Gerald ’ s room ready ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Yes , I think so . I ’ ll just go and find out .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I was so delighted to see the announcement in the morning ’ s paper . I offer my very warmest congratulations .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Thanks , so much .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ ve known Gerald for ages . I ’ m delighted to see him on the way to such a happy marriage . I couldn ’ t have wished him to get engaged to any one nicer than you .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: It ’ s all so romantic , isn ’ t it ? It ought to be an answer to a cynical creature like you to see the course of true love run so smoothly .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: To GERALD .I offer you also my best congratulations . I think you ’ re very lucky .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Stiffly .Thank you , very much . I suppose I have my usual room ?

lg.l: Yes .
lg.stage: He goes into the house . LADY SELLENGER and NELLIE accompany AUNT ELIZA . MRS . DOT is left alone with BLENKINSOP .
lg.l: James !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Hulloa !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Do you love me ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Passionately .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Stamping her foot .Don ’ t be so silly .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You can ’ t expect me to be so uncivil as to say no .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But I ’ m perfectly serious .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Are you , by Jove ? That alters the matter . In that case the answer is in the negative .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And is there the least chance of your falling in love with me ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not so long as I remain in full possession of my senses .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Do you want to marry me ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Really you embarrass me very much .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Don ’ t hedge .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It ’ s a little disconcerting to have a pistol put to your head in the form of a proposal of marriage .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m not making you a proposal of marriage , idiot .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Then I should very much like to know what you are doing .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m asking you a very simple and ordinary question .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Thank God , it ’ s not one that women ask often .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I never saw any one out of whom it ’ s harder to get a straight answer .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You must make allowances for a pardonable agitation .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: James , do you want to marry me ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: No , bless you !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Are you quite sure ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Positive .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Would nothing induce you to marry me ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With a sigh of relief .Then you may kiss my hand .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Doing so .You ’ re not hurt ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m infinitely relieved .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: And Freddie , the dear boy , says he can read a woman at a glance .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now listen to me quite seriously . I want you to do something for me .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Nervously .We ’ ve put marriage out of the question , haven ’ t we ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Generously .You may ask anything else of me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I want you to let me make love to you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: My dear friend , this is very surprising .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: There are people who ’ d welcome the proposal with alacrity .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: For how long ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Only for a week .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You ’ re sure it ’ s not in earnest ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Quite sure .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: And what have I got to do ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , you ’ ve got to look as if you liked it .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Sombrely .Of course , it sounds very delightful .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You must show a coming-on disposition , you know , or I can do nothing .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Do you want me to make love to you ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m afraid it ’ s asking a great deal of you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not at all . Not at all . But I wish you ’ d tell me what your little game is .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Ah , here ’ s Aunt Eliza . The very person I wanted .AUNT ELIZA comes on the terrace from the house . Impulsively .Aunt Eliza , will you be a perfect brick ? Will you do something for me , that ’ s an awful nuisance ?

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: My dear , why on earth are you so excited ? Of course I ’ ll do anything in reason for you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But it ’ s not in reason .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Well , I ’ ll do it all the same .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I want you to take a motor and bolt up to London and get a special licence .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: A special licence !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: A special licence !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Catching sight of his face .Get two special licences . They ’ re always useful things to have in a house .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: But they must be made out to certain names .

lg.l: Must they ? How stupid ! Well , have one made out for Frederick Perkins and
Eleanor Sellenger .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: My dear child , you must be crazy .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now don ’ t argue , but do as I tell you . If two young things are thrown together with a certain amount of skill they always marry .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: But they hardly know one another .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: If people waited to know one another before they married , the world wouldn ’ t be so grossly over-populated as it is now .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: You ’ re certainly quite crazy .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No , I ’ m not . I shall never get Gerald to break his word . My only chance is with Nellie .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Uneasily .But you ’ ve told her to get two licences .

lg.l: Make the second one out in the names of James Blenkinsop and Frances
Annandale Worthley .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I absolutely refuse .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But you must let me . You can ’ t leave an old friend in the lurch .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It ’ s all very fine to invoke the claims of friendship , but it ’ s carrying it rather far when you pay three guineas for a special licence .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear man , I can ’ t drag you to the altar .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I ’ m beginning to think you ’ re capable of anything .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But don ’ t you see , you idiot , that I want to marry Gerald Hollington ? And I ’ m eating my heart out .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Crossly .It ’ s evidently a diet that agrees with you . You ’ re growing fat on it .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Don ’ t be spiteful . I ’ ve not gained half a pound in the last five years .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: And how on earth are you going to get Freddie and Nellie Sellenger to use this licence ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Never mind , leave everything to me . And make haste to get up to London .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Very well , I ’ ll go at once .

div.stage: Just as AUNT ELIZA is going into the house LADY SELLENGER comes out , followed by NELLIE ; AUNT ELIZA stops and listens to the conversation from the doorway .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I hope you ’ ve found everything you wanted .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Oh , yes , thanks . I ’ m quite delighted with the view from my room .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Come and sit down . I have something very serious I want to talk to you about .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Dear Mr. Blenkinsop , do take Nellie for a little stroll in the garden .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , but it concerns Nellie , and I want her to hear .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I perceive you are inclined to think that the serious cannot fail to be improper , Lady Sellenger .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Be quiet , you horrible cynic .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , a most ridiculous thing has happened , and I want Nellie to help me .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear , it ’ s so unfortunate , but my nephew has fallen head over ears in love with you .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Nonsense !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I can ’ t understand it . After all , he ’ s only seen you once , and you can ’ t have exchanged more than a dozen words .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: How very annoying !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And it ’ s so unexpected , because he ’ s not at all the sort of boy who falls in and out of love with every pretty girl he meets . I think you ’ re his first passion , and he ’ s inclined to take it very seriously .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Poor boy , I can afford to sympathise with him now that Nellie is safely engaged to Gerald Hollington .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: It ’ s really rather flattering , isn ’ t it ? But how on earth d ’ you know ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: He tells me everything . You see I ’ ve always tried to be his friend as well as his aunt . He has no secrets from me .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You ’ ll tell us next that a boy who ’ s been to Eton and Oxford has a pure and innocent mind .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear child , he simply raves about you . He ’ s been talking of nothing else ever since you met .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: But doesn ’ t he know that Nellie is going to be married at the end of the season ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Of course , he does . I ’ ve dinned it into his ears , but it seems to have no effect on him . He ’ s the sort of lover that will hear of no obstacles . It ’ s really quite pathetic to hear the passionate harangues that he pours into my ears .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: What sort of things does he say ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear , I suppose very much the same as Gerald .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: No one could accuse Gerald of being a passionate lover .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
