sp.p: I ’ m very glad he ’ s not . He ’ s going to be your husband , and that ’ s more satisfactory than any amount of pretty speeches .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I could wish that he talked to me of something besides the weather and the Royal Academy .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: My dear child , what are you saying ? Gerald has a charming nature and the very highest principles .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Imitating her pompous manner .To say nothing of a peerage and a considerable income .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: He certainly has every advantage over poor Freddie , who is nobody in particular and hasn ’ t a penny to bless himself with .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I think he ’ s awfully nice .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , that ’ s just what I don ’ t want you to think . I shouldn ’ t have said anything to you about his — mad infatuation , only I want you to be very careful .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Of course . It ’ s quite natural .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: What do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , I want you to be very good and sweet and help me to cure him . I ’ d send him away , only it would have no effect . I thought if he saw you again he might find out that you have at least one or two faults . At present he thinks you too perfect for words .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I ’ m not that , really .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I didn ’ t think you were . I want you to promise that you ’ ll do nothing that he can in the least take as encouragement . I want you to be very distant and very cold .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Of course , I ’ ll be only too glad to do anything I can .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You ’ d be doing him a real kindness if you could snub him at every opportunity . Then you must avoid him as much as you can . Of course , you ’ ll be very much with Gerald while you ’ re down here .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Of course . The dears , they ’ ve not seen one another for a year , and they have an infinity of things to discuss .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It ’ ll be quite easy for you to show my poor Freddie that he ’ s only making a prodigious fool of himself .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I feel so sorry for him .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You will do what you can , won ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I ’ ll make it quite plain to him at once that he mustn ’ t care for me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Treat it as an impertinence that you resent .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I ’ ll do that on the first opportunity .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I know you have the sweetest nature in the world , but if you could be really brutal to him at once , it would cure him instantly .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I can be horrid when I like .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m sure you can . I put infinite reliance in your tact .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: And now I think we really might take a little turn in the garden before tea .Seeing that NELLIE , instead of accompanying her , strolls towards the house .Where are you going , Nellie ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Stopping .I ’ ve just remembered I must write a letter . I ’ ll join you in five minutes .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: To BLENKINSOP and MRS . DOT who are getting up .Oh , don ’ t let me disturb you , I shall enjoy wandering about and looking at the flowers by myself .

div.stage: She goes away . Just as NELLIE is entering the house FREDDIE comes out . She gives him a glance and as she passes , drops a rose . FREDDIE picks it up and comes forward .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You monster !

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: What ’ s the matter ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Give me that flower !

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I shall do nothing of the sort . I shall put it in my button-hole .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Freddie , I ’ ve come to the conclusion that you want a holiday . I wish you to pack up your things at once and go to Brighton for a week . You ’ re looking pale and tired . I ’ m sure you ’ ve been working too hard .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Oh , rot ! I ’ m as fit as a fiddle .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Don ’ t you agree with me , James ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Certainly . I think a change of air is distinctly indicated .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: But I can ’ t go away when you ’ ve got people in the house . Besides , who ’ s to look after your correspondence ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear boy , your health is the chief thing . I should never forgive myself if you came to any harm while you were my secretary . I ’ ll write my letters myself .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Besides , I shall be here , and I ’ ll do all I can to help you .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I don ’ t believe I ’ m pale .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You only have to look at yourself .

div.stage: She takes out a little pocket mirror and hands it to him .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Let ’ s look at your tongue .He puts it out .Tut , tut , tut .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Look here , there ’ s something behind this .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You ’ re too clever , my boy .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I see through your little game . Aunt Dot , you want to get rid of me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: How can you be so absurd ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Now , I wonder what your reason is .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Shall we tell him the truth ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Yes , perhaps you ’ d better . He ’ s a very bright boy .

lg.l: Well , the fact is , Freddie , a dreadful thing has happened . Poor Nellie
Sellenger is desperately in love with you .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I don ’ t see why you should want me to go away on that account .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Good lord , man , don ’ t be so self-satisfied . Aren ’ t you surprised , aren ’ t you dumfounded that a pretty girl should fall in love with you ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I thought it meant something when she dropped that rose .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Bless my stars , the dolt takes it as a matter of course .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ m awfully flattered and all that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But not exactly surprised ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: It ’ s not fair to ask a fellow a question like that .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: At all events , you see now the necessity for depriving us for a time of your charming society .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Nothing will induce me to desert a post of danger . I ’ m going to face the music .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Don ’ t be such an ass . It ’ s not you we ’ re thinking of , it ’ s that unfortunate girl .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know why you think she ’ s unfortunate .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But , my dear boy , she ’ s engaged to Gerald Hollington . Don ’ t you see how serious the whole thing is ? The only chance is for you to go away . We must try and make her forget you .

lg.l: I don ’ t want to do anybody a bad turn . I wouldn ’ t do anything to queer
Gerald ’ s pitch for worlds .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You must combine with us in order to save her from herself .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: There ’ s no use in her eating her heart out for you , when she must inevitably marry Gerald .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Poor old Gerald , I told you he wasn ’ t the sort of chap a girl would be desperately in love with .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: The acumen you have shown does credit to your years .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Still , you know , I don ’ t think it ’ s wise for me to go away . Don ’ t you think it would be rather marked ? And they always say that absence makes the heart grow fonder .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It was a woman who invented that proverb . There ’ s no truth in it .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: What else can you suggest ? The fact remains that Nellie must be cured of this — of this passion .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: My own idea is that the best thing is for me to hang on here as if I knew nothing about it . I ’ ll take care to be very distant . I ’ ll ignore her as much as I can .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Will you promise to do that ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Yes , rather . I ’ ll let her see that I ’ m really a deuced dissipated dog .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Don ’ t let her think you ’ re too great a devil with the ladies , or that ’ ll be the last straw . If there ’ s one thing a woman likes it ’ s a really bad man . She ’ ll start reforming you , and then there ’ ll be no holding her back .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No , you must seem rather dull and stupid . Let her think you ’ re a bit of a milksop .

div.stage: FREDDIE looks at them suspiciously .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Look here , you ’ re not pulling my leg all the time , are you ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear , I should never take such a liberty .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I don ’ t believe a word of what you ’ ve told me . Why should she care for me ? You ’ ve simply been humbugging me right and left .

div.stage: For a moment MRS . DOT is taken aback , but she sees LADY SELLENGER coming through the garden with GERALD .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Here ’ s Lady Sellenger . You won ’ t accuse her of trying to make a fool of you .LADY SELLENGER and GERALD appear .I ’ ve just been talking to Freddie about — about your girl .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Oh yes .To FREDDIE .My poor boy , you ’ re in a very difficult position .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Then you know all about it , too ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I really feel for you very much . You ’ ll want a great deal of tact and a great deal of courage . But you must do your duty .

div.stage: She turns aside to BLENKINSOP .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: In an undertone to FREDDIE .Now have I been pulling your leg ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Poor girl !

div.stage: He goes into the house .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Looking at him as he goes .What a beautiful and touching thing love is .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You must take care , Lady Sellenger . You ’ re growing sentimental .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: But I ’ ve always been as sentimental as a schoolgirl in my heart . Only , so long as Nellie ’ s future was unarranged , I was obliged to keep a tight hand on myself .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Of course , Jimmie laughs ; he doesn ’ t know what love is .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Have you never been loved for yourself , Mr. Blenkinsop ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I have , but I have always found it deuced expensive .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid Blenkinsop doesn ’ t set much store on the gentle sex .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Don ’ t call them gentle . They ’ re very much rougher than men .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Stop him , or he ’ ll utter a whole string of horrors .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Have you never watched the gentle sex fight and push and scramble as it gets into the Hammersmith bus ? I assure you , the unlucky man who finds himself in that seething feminine crowd is fortunate if he escapes without losing an eye or half his teeth . And have you seen the fury of the gentle sex at a sale as they seize some worthless fragment , and the bitterness with which they haggle ? The other day I was in the Army and Navy Stores , and two women were standing on the stairs , discussing their servants , so that no one could pass up and down . I took off my hat and said : Excuse me , would you allow me to pass . They moved barely two inches , and one of them said in a loud voice to the other : What an impertinent man . The gentle sex ! Yesterday I was hanging on a strap in a crowded train coming from the city , and I saw a pale-faced weary clerk give up his seat to a strong and bouncing girl . She took it without saying thank you , because she was a lady and he wasn ’ t a gentleman . Then a tired old woman came in and stood , but the bouncing girl never thought of giving up the seat to her . The gentle sex ! They have such tender hearts they couldn ’ t bear to hurt a fly . Have you ever seen a woman get out of a bus ten yards before her destination in order to save the wretched horses another start ? Not much . Have you ever known a woman of fashion who sends her maid to bed when she knows she won ’ t be in till four in the morning ? Not much . And is there anything like the insolence with which a woman treats her social inferiors of the same sex ? Is it men who put on their backs the sealskins that are torn off the living bodies of helpless brutes ? Is it men who put on their hats the beautiful birds of the forest ? It ’ s the gentle sex . Boys are taught manners . They are taught to take off their hats and hold open the door for their sisters . They are taught to fetch and carry for women , and to give up the front seat in life to women . But what are girls taught ? Girls are taught etiquette , and that , I suppose , makes them in due course the gentle sex .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Every one knows you ’ re a horrible cynic , so there can ’ t be a word of truth in anything you say .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Q. E. D .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Here comes Nellie .

div.stage: NELLIE comes in , having changed her dress . She now wears a very pretty white frock , all flounces and furbelows , and a large white hat . At the same moment from the other side FREDDIE enters . He also has changed , and is now in spotless white .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With a laugh , whispering to BLENKINSOP .They ’ ve both changed their clothes .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Would you like to come for a row , Nellie ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I ’ m too tired . Won ’ t you go with Mrs . Dot ? I ’ ll rest here till tea-time .

div.stage: NELLIE sits down , and the others go .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Personally , I must walk . I sacrifice all my inclinations to my fear of growing too stout . I often wonder if we shall get our good dinners in heaven that we ’ ve done without on earth .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It ’ s generally understood that we shall only get our deserts .

div.stage: NELLIE watches them go from over her shoulder . She sees that FREDDIE is hanging back . She smiles and elaborately disregards him . He comes forward and leans over her chair .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Aren ’ t you going with the others ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Do you mind if I stay with you ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I like it .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Jolly here , isn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Awfully jolly .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ ve not congratulated you on your engagement yet .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I didn ’ t expect you would .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t know .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: It seems a long time since we first met , doesn ’ t it ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Because I seem to know you so well .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: You ’ re very easy to get to know , aren ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I say , you look just like another rose in this garden .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I suppose you say that to every girl who sits here ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ ve never said it to any one but you .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: They tell me you ’ re very impressionable .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: They lie .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I think I shall take off my hat .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Yes , do .

div.stage: She proceeds to do so . She pretends that she cannot .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh , how stupid of me ! Something has caught .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: May I help you ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I ’ m giving you a lot of trouble .

div.stage: He helps her , and she gives a little scream .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Oh , I ’ m so sorry . Did I hurt you ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: No , but it tickled .

div.stage: She takes off the hat . One hand of hers remains in his . Their eyes meet for the first time , and they smile .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I say , what a pretty hand you have ! It looks so white on mine , doesn ’ t it ?

div.stage: MRS . DOT creeps back and stands behind a bush , so that she cannot be seen .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I rather like your hand . It ’ s so strong and brown .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You know , you ’ re awfully easy to get on with . Sometimes I feel dreadfully shy and nervous with women , but I can think of all sorts of things I want to say to you .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I seem to have known you all my life .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Impulsively .Isn ’ t it jolly here ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Awfully jolly .

div.stage: He looks at her for a moment .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I want to ask you something . You won ’ t be angry , will you ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: May I kiss you ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: It ’ s awfully unkind of you .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: You shouldn ’ t have asked .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Shouldn ’ t I ? I wanted to , badly .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: There are some things one should do without asking .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You are a brick .

div.stage: He kisses her . As he does so , HOLLINGTON comes in and sees them . He stops for a moment in astonishment , then withdraws .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Let ’ s go on the river , shall we ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I told Gerald I was too tired .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Oh , hang Gerald !

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: We might go and play the piano in the drawing-room .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ m awfully fond of music . Cake-walks , and things like that , you know .

div.stage: They get up . MRS . DOT comes forward .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Are you going ? I thought you were tired .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: We ’ re just going to look at the kitchen garden .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ ve told Miss Sellenger that you ’ ve got some most awfully good carrots .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: As they go to the house .That ’ s not the way , you know .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Coolly .I ’ m only just going to get a handkerchief .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , I see . I beg your pardon .

div.stage: They go . GERALD comes forward . He is rather grave and solemn .

lg.l: What a picture they make , don ’ t they ? I can ’ t tell you how much I like
Nellie .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You ’ ve come to the conclusion that the cut of her skirt ’ s all right .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Ah , you mustn ’ t recall what I said when I was in a temper . You know , I ’ m rather touched by her obvious affection for you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s very good of you to say so .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It ’ s so nice to see two people head over ears in love with one another .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I wouldn ’ t be so presumptuous as to think Nellie was so much in love with me as all that .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear boy , I ’ ve just had proof of it .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Have you ? That ’ s more than I have .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And is dear Lady Sellenger going to live with you when you ’ re married ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Look here , Dot , what ’ s the meaning of all this ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Much surprised .Of what ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Why did you ask us all down ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Because I ’ m of a hospitable turn of mind . Didn ’ t you want to come ? I ’ m so sorry .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You ’ ve utterly ignored me since I arrived .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Ironically .Much as I should have liked to devote myself exclusively to your entertainment , I ’ ve been really obliged to remember that my other guests had equal claims upon me .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I should very much like to take you by the shoulders and give you a good shaking .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I don ’ t think you ’ re in a very good temper to-day .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Crossly .Pardon me , I ’ m in the best possible temper .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You certainly ought to be with the prospect of spending a week in almost uninterrupted tête-à-tête with the object of your affections .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I can ’ t make you out . You ’ re so changed since last we met .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You see , last time I thought I was in love with you . Now I know I ’ m not .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Bitterly .I ’ m glad you ’ ve got over it so quickly .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Really , you couldn ’ t wish me to continue eating my heart out for a young man , however charming , who is going to marry somebody else .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Mockingly .Well ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I was a fool to think you ever cared at all .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But why should you think it when you took the greatest pains to assure me that you didn ’ t care two straws for me ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Quickly .I didn ’ t !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You did !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I didn ’ t !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Then you did care for me ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I never said that .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Anyhow , whatever your sentiments were , it would gratify your self-esteem to think that I was languishing with a hopeless passion .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s cruel of you to laugh at me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: By the way , are you by any chance in love with me now ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You have no right to ask me that question .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My dear boy , I ’ m not keeping you from spending an idyllic afternoon with Nellie . You ’ ve forced this conversation upon me . I assure you it ’ s most distasteful .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: If I had married you , I should certainly have beaten you with a big stick .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: What do you think is my chief characteristic ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: That ’ s a question I can answer . The most confounded and aggravating unreasonableness that I ever saw .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Nonsense . It ’ s obvious that my chief characteristic is a sweet and yielding nature . But as there ’ s no likelihood of our agreeing on that , what do you think is the second ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Obstinacy .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , I prefer to call it strength of mind . Now , I ’ ll acknowledge that I was in love with you — a month ago . That ’ s a feather in your cap .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , I wish we were back again . I ’ ve had such rotten luck .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But when I saw that my sweetness was likely to be wasted on the desert air , I made up my mind to cure myself . First I cried for two days .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Dot .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No , don ’ t sympathise . I have rather a high colour , and when I ’ ve had a good cry it always improves my complexion . After that , I ordered some new frocks , and I bought a diamond necklace that I ’ d been hankering after for some time .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: And that thoroughly consoled you , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It helped . Then I came to the conclusion that there were as good fish in the sea as ever came out of it . I thought you over . After all , you ’ re not really very good-looking , are you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m not aware that I ever made any pretence of being so .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And I ’ m sure no one could accuse you of being extremely amusing .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I have no doubt I ’ m excessively dull .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I couldn ’ t help seeing that you ’ d suit Nellie much better than you would have suited me . She has that comfortable stupidity which the average Englishman looks upon as the highest recommendation for a wife .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s charming of you to say so .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: She is a little dull , isn ’ t she ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I don ’ t think her so .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Doesn ’ t time hang rather heavily on your hands now and then ? Isn ’ t it difficult to find topics of conversation ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I don ’ t find it so .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Ah — she does .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: And the long and short of it is that the emotion which you dignify with the name of love , had entirely disappeared after a week .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Make it ten days to be on the safe side .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I congratulate you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You wouldn ’ t have it otherwise , surely ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Then all is for the best in the best of all possible worlds .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Furiously .I think you must be quite heartless .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Delighted .Ah , that ’ s what I said to you a month ago , Philippine .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Now , perhaps , you ’ d like to know what my feeling is towards you ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: No , I ’ m quite indifferent , thanks !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Well , I shall tell you for all that . It ’ s a joke to you , and you can afford to laugh at it .

div.stage: He goes up to her and then stops suddenly .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh ! My poor heart went pit-a-pat . I thought you were going to kiss me .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I hate you . And I wish I ’ d never set eyes on you .

div.stage: He turns on his heel and walks out quickly . As soon as he is gone MRS . DOT begins to dance a break-down . She cocks a snook after him .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ ll marry you yet , you beast , I ’ ll marry you yet .

div.stage: BLENKINSOP comes in .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: What on earth is the matter with you now ?

div.stage: From inside is heard the sound of a cake-walk .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Come on .

div.stage: She seizes him and begins to dance .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Unhand me , woman !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , you dear , you dear , you dear .

div.stage: She flings both arms round his neck and kisses him soundly . At this moment GERALD returns .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I beg your pardon . I forgot my hat .

div.stage: He takes it and goes out stiffly . MRS . DOT bursts into a shriek of laughter .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: That ’ s all very fine . But what about my character ? END OF THE SECOND ACT

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: A hall in MRS. WORTHLEY ’ S house on the River .
GERALD and NELLIE are seated in arm-chairs . She stifles a yawn . Then he yawns .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Yawning .I never saw any one who yawned so much as you .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Ironically .I suppose you ’ ve never looked at yourself in the glass ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Is your family very long-lived , Gerald ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Rather surprised .Are you already asking yourself how you ’ ll look in widow ’ s weeds ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: You may very well live for forty years , mayn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: My maternal grandfather survived to plague his descendants to the ripe age of ninety-seven .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: How many days are there in forty years ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I should think about fifteen thousand .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Has it occurred to you that we may eat fifteen thousand breakfasts sitting opposite one another , and fifteen thousand luncheons , and fifteen thousand dinners ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Gloomily .Yes , it had occurred to me .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: And how do you look upon the prospect ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Grimly .It fills me with satisfaction , naturally .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Abruptly .I suppose you ’ re very much in love with me ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What an extraordinary question !

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I don ’ t think any one but a lunatic would describe you as an ardent lover .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Coldly .I regret that my behaviour doesn ’ t meet with your satisfaction .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Do you know that since we became definitely engaged you ’ ve never told me that you cared for me ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Apologetically .Yes , I ought to have done that , oughtn ’ t I ? I suppose I thought you ’ d take it for granted .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Every girl likes a suspicion of romance thrown over her love-affairs .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Your mother will tell you that the certainty of marriage is much more satisfactory .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Dryly .You would have made an excellent husband — for mother .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Have you noticed that when we do think of something to talk about , we get perilously near a squabble ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I sometimes think it would be better to quarrel outright now and then than be always so desperately polite to one another .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m afraid I have an admirable temper .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Mother always says you have all the virtues .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Shall we look at the Sketch together ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: We ’ ve looked at the Sketch together three times .Following his eye , which goes to other illustrated papers on the table .And the Illustrated , and the Sphere , and the Graphic .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Then what would you like to do ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I should like to SCREAM .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Would you , by George ? So would I .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh , Gerald , let ’ s have a good scream together .

div.stage: Enter LADY SELLENGER and MRS . DOT .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: With a bland smile .What a picture they make !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Acidly .It ’ s quite charming to see two young things so engrossed in one another ’ s society .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Now , you really mustn ’ t waste this beautiful afternoon . You must go and have a nice long walk together .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: We had a nice long walk this morning .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Sweetly .Then why don ’ t you go on the river ? You can take your tea with you and spend the whole afternoon there .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: We spent the whole afternoon on the river yesterday , and you kindly gave us our tea to take with us .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: It reminds me of the happy days when I was engaged to your poor father , Nellie . We were just like you and Gerald . We couldn ’ t bear to be out of one another ’ s sight . Now , run and get your hat , darling .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh , mamma , I ’ ve got the most dreadful headache that I ’ ve ever had in my life , and I must really go and lie down .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Nonsense . An afternoon in the fresh air with Gerald is just the thing to put you right .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I ’ m so sorry , but I have some very important letters to write . I must catch the post .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Sweetly .You ’ ll have lots of time when you come in . The post doesn ’ t go till after dinner .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: If you make excuses like that , poor Nellie will think she bores you already .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: In that case I shall be only too glad to go on the river .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Take my sunshade , darling . You won ’ t want a hat .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Savagely .Thank you , dear .

div.stage: NELLIE and GERALD go out gloomily .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Just like humming-birds , aren ’ t they ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Do you mean turtle-doves by any chance ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I was never very good at natural history .... Dear Mrs. Worthley , I must really thank you for the tact with which you ’ ve thrown Gerald and Nellie in one another ’ s society every moment of the day .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I can flatter myself that they ’ ve thoroughly enjoyed their week here .

div.stage: AUNT ELIZA , comes in with BLENKINSOP .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: With a look of intelligence .Dear Mr. Blenkinsop , you wicked , wicked cynic .Meaningly .I shall go and lie down . Are you coming upstairs , Miss MacGregor ?

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: In one minute .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I want to have a little talk with you .As BLENKINSOP holds open the door for her , in a whisper .Aren ’ t I tactful ?

div.stage: LADY SELLENGER goes out .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: What villainy is that old woman up to now ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You idiot ! Don ’ t you see that she ’ s discovered the passion that devours our hearts — your manly bosom and my timid , fluttering heart — and she wants to leave us alone .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I ’ m beginning to feel very unwell .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Archly .Wouldn ’ t you be rather flattered if I really were in love with you ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Alarmed .Dot , don ’ t make these horrible suggestions . You make my flesh creep .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But you ’ ve been so cold , you haven ’ t given me a chance .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Cold ! Heaven knows what would have happened if I ’ d given you any encouragement . I ’ ve never been able to take my eyes off the ground without finding yours fixed on me with the languishing expression of a dying duck in a thunderstorm . I ’ ve never been able to go near you without your stroking me as if I were a velvet cushion or a Persian cat . I ’ ve not eaten a single meal in peace in case you suddenly took it into your head to press my foot under the table .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: What would you have done if I had ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: With outraged dignity .I should have screamed ! And the thought of that special licence has cast a chill in my heart . I don ’ t know what it ’ s all coming to . You are my witness , Miss MacGregor , that I won ’ t marry her , however deeply she compromises me .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Smiling .I am your witness .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: She shan ’ t make an honest man of me .

div.stage: MRS . DOT takes from a drawer of the escritoire one of the licences .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Smiling .Frances Annandale Worthley — James Blenkinsop .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I feel as though some one were walking over my grave .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: But how on earth are you going to get Nellie Sellenger and Freddie to use the other licence ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: When the right moment comes I shall leave it under their noses , and allow them to draw what consequences they choose .... If any woman ever earned a husband , I have . I ’ ve taken every opportunity to snub Gerald till he can hardly contain himself with rage . I ’ ve thrown him in Nellie ’ s company till they ’ re both so bored they could almost cry . I ’ ve been constantly on the watch to prevent Nellie and Freddie from having two minutes by themselves till they can hardly bear the sight of me . And I ’ ve made love to you with a persistence that would have melted the heart of a fish . If I fail , it will be your fault .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: But what on earth do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Good heavens , throw a little passion into your behaviour . Look at me as though you ’ d never seen any one so ravishing in your life . When you take my hand , hold it as if you would never let it go .

div.stage: She takes his hand .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Remember , there ’ s no one but Miss MacGregor present .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With a yearning glance .Look into my eyes like this .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Don ’ t . You make me feel very uncomfortable .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Impatiently .Oh , you ’ re too stupid . You ’ re a stock and a stone . You ’ re an owl . You ’ re a ridiculous idiot .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Temper , temper .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You ’ ll ruin my whole life , because you ’ re such a perfect fool that you can ’ t make love to a woman .

div.stage: She breaks away from him and begins to cry . He walks up and down , then looks at her with a smile . He makes a sign to MISS MACGREGOR that MRS . DOT cannot see .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: In a different voice .Dot , this little game of ours has lasted long enough .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Sobbing in her handkerchief .Yes , it has . I ’ m sick to death of the whole thing .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You asked me to play a part , and you didn ’ t know that it might be deadly earnest .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Fiddlesticks !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I have a secret that I can no longer keep from you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Well , tell it to the horse-marines .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Dot , I love you !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , don ’ t be so silly .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: But I tell you I ’ m not joking .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Thank heaven for that . I ’ m weary of your bad jokes .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: The thing started as a bad joke , but it has ended in something very different . A change has come over me , and I ’ m ashamed .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Looking up .Eh ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Don ’ t you see that I ’ m a different man ? Dot , it ’ s you who ’ ve changed me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I really believe he ’ s waking up .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: If I was shy and awkward , it ’ s because I wouldn ’ t give in to myself . I was overwhelmed . I couldn ’ t understand .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: That ’ s much better . There really is a ring of emotion in your voice .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: How shouldn ’ t there be , when I ’ m saying at last what has trembled on the tip of my tongue for ten days ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Delighted .There ! That ’ s just the tone I want . Talk with that quiver in your voice when you ask me to pass you the mustard at dinner .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I lie awake at night thinking of you , and when I fall asleep I seem to hold you in my arms .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: That ’ s splendid . Why couldn ’ t you say all this before ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Dot , Dot , don ’ t torture me . Don ’ t you see I mean it .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: What !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I ’ m not jesting now . I wish to heaven I were .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Forcing a laugh .My dear James , you ’ re really piling it on too much .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You must be mad or blind . Can ’ t you feel that I love you ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Don ’ t be so absurd . You know you ’ re only — you ’ re only pulling my leg .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Oh , I ’ ve been a perfect ass . I should never have consented to play this ghastly trick . If you only knew what tortures I ’ ve suffered !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: He isn ’ t really serious , Aunt Eliza ?

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: Smiling .Upon my soul , it looks very much like it .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: What did you expect ? You ’ ve played on my heart-strings as though they were an instrument that had no feeling . You ’ ve put a caress into every tone of your voice .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Ruefully .Of course , I am fascinating . I can ’ t deny that .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: When you touched my hand , every nerve of my body thrilled .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You ’ re not really in love with me ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Passionately .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You ’ re ridiculous , James Blenkinsop .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I was a fool . I played with fire , and I never dreamed I ’ d burn myself .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But you mustn ’ t be in love with me . I won ’ t hear of it .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It ’ s too late to say that now . I adore you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But what on earth ’ s to be done ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You must marry me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Nothing will induce me to do anything of the sort .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Going up to her with outstretched arms .You can ’ t realise the wealth of tenderness and affection which I ’ ll lavish upon you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Go away ! Don ’ t come near me .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Why should you care for Gerald ? Do you think if he loved you , he would let a trifling engagement with somebody else stand in the way ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: The fact is that men are never to be trusted .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I can ’ t live without you now . I ’ ll give up my whole life to make you happy .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But I ’ m in love with Gerald . I ’ m not in love with you . I shall never be in love with you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You owe me something for all the agony you ’ ve made me endure . Dot , remember that licence . It was bought in jest , but the Archbishop of Canterbury was in earnest .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: But my dear James , for heaven ’ s sake be reasonable . You know just as well as I do that you ’ re not a marrying man .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Give me the chance , and you ’ ll see .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m sure you wouldn ’ t like me . I ’ m horrid really .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I know that you ’ re full of faults , but , bless you , I love them all .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ ve got a beastly temper .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I dote upon you when I see your eyes flash with anger .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ m awfully extravagant , and if the Government brings in temperance legislation I shall be ruined .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I ’ m rich . I should look upon it as the greatest happiness to spend my last penny to gratify your smallest wish .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I won ’ t marry you . I won ’ t marry you . I won ’ t !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Dot , Dot !

div.stage: He catches her in his arms and kisses her . At this moment GERALD comes in , MRS . DOT breaks away from BLENKINSOP . There is an awkward pause .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: To GERALD .I thought you were on the river .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Hang the river !

div.stage: She goes to the door , which BLENKINSOP opens for her . She goes out . As AUNT ELIZA follows , he speaks to her in a low tone .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: There ’ s passion for you .

sp.speaker: AUNT ELIZA
sp.p: You brutes , you can all do it . You positively made my heart beat .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: What did Miss MacGregor say ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: A vague suggestion of bigamy if I understood correctly .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Frigidly .I ’ m afraid I came at an inopportune moment .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It appears to be one of your happy little ways .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Every one seems to kiss every one else in this house .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: With effrontery .You have only to envelop Lady Sellenger in your arms , and the picture will be complete .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Would you kindly explain this incident ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: If you ’ ll allow me to say so , I really can ’ t see that it ’ s any business of yours .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Hotly .Look here , Blenkinsop , you ’ ve got no right to play your fool-tricks with Mrs . Dot . She ’ s a very excitable and thoughtless woman . She ’ s ....

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Oh , damn you !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Not at all , not at all .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Angrily .What the deuce is the meaning of all this tomfoolery ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Blandly .I suppose you couldn ’ t be a little more civil , could you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Look here , Blenkinsop , the best thing you can do is to receive a telegram that requires your immediate presence in town .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Thanks very much , but I ’ m extremely comfortable down here .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You ’ d be rather surprised if I threw you out of the window , wouldn ’ t you ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I should not only be surprised , but I should look upon it as an odious familiarity .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Would you like to know my private opinion of you ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Spare me my blushes , dear boy . It always embarrasses me to be flattered to my face .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You silly old fool .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I believe you ’ re considerably annoyed .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Not in the least . What the dickens is there about you that should annoy me ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Now that I come to think of it , you are certainly in a passion . Your face is red , your attire is disordered , and you have a slight squint in your eye .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: My dear fellow , if I hadn ’ t the best temper in the world , I should kick you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You ’ d far better go and lie down . You ’ ll only say something which you ’ ll regret .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I suppose you ’ re not for a moment under the impression that Mrs . Dot cares twopence about you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: May I ask how that can in the least concern you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Mrs . Dot is an old friend of mine . I ’ m not going to see her made ridiculous by a conceited nincompoop .

lg.l: By the way , has it slipped your memory that you ’ re engaged to Miss
Sellenger ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Good Lord , no !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I daresay you wish it had .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: That ’ s a confounded impertinent thing to say .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: My dear fellow , I never saw any one with less common sense in my life . Surely it ’ s not very extraordinary that the same tender passion which inflames the chaste breasts of yourself and Miss Sellenger , should attack the equally chaste breasts of myself and Mrs. Worthley .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Don ’ t talk such twaddle .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I suppose you ’ d be considerably astonished if I told you that I ’ d just asked Mrs . Dot to be my wife .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: She must have screamed with laughter .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You noticed her unconcealed hilarity when you came in .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Going up to him quickly .You don ’ t mean it !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: No man is quite safe from the toils of women till he ’ s safely in his grave . And even then a feminine worm probably makes a dead set at him .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: And does Mrs . Dot — reciprocate your affection ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Really you ask me a very delicate question .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: By the great Harry , the man thinks she ’ s in love with him .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Rather indignant .And pray , why shouldn ’ t she be just as much in love with me as with you ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: With a burst of laughter .Ha , ha , ha .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: What the blazes are you laughing at ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Ha ! ha ! ha !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Shut up , you blithering idiot !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Still laughing .She has made a fool of you . Ha ! ha ! ha !Seriously .And did you really think any woman would care for you ? My poor Blenkinsop ! My poor , poor Blenkinsop !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You ’ re a jackanapes , sir , you ’ re an impudent jackanapes . And why not , pray ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Furiously .Because you ’ re revolting to look upon , and your conversation is inexpressibly tedious .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It ’ s charming of you to say so .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: If you want to marry any one , marry Lady Sellenger .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You are evidently under the impression that if a woman can ’ t be so fortunate as to marry you , she had far better retire into a nunnery .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: You ’ re a cantankerous cynic and a fatuous donkey .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I like the delicacy with which you express your appreciation of my merits .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Listen to me , Blenkinsop ! Clear out of the house before you make a greater mess of things than you have already . Mrs . Dot would as soon marry her groom as marry you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You think it ’ s quite impossible that she should ever have dreamt of such a thing ?

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Not only impossible , but grotesque .

div.stage: BLENKINSOP goes to the drawer in which is the licence and takes it out .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Perhaps , then , it would interest you to inspect this document .

div.stage: GERALD takes it and looks at it , dumfounded .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s a special licence .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: So much less bother than banns , you know .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: James Blenkinsop .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: And Frances Annandale Worthley .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: It ’ s a mistake ! It ’ s all a preposterous mistake .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You see , the Archbishop of Canterbury calls me his right well-beloved brother . Friendly , isn ’ t it ?

div.stage: GERALD violently tears it in pieces and flings them on the ground . BLENKINSOP gives a sigh of relief . GERALD stalks out of the room into the garden . BLENKINSOP goes to the door and waves his hand at him . MRS . DOT comes in . She has discovered that BLENKINSOP has been making a fool of her .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: He ’ s torn up your precious licence .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Quickly .Which one ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Ours , of course . Three guineas gone bang , my dear .

lg.l: I ’ m reckoning how many bottles of beer the
British public will have to drink for us to buy another .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: But your refusal of my hand will happily prevent you from going to that expense . Thereby considerably forwarding the cause of temperance .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With an assumption of overwhelming gravity .James , I have been thinking over all you said , and I am willing to marry you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: A chill going down his spine .I thank you from the bottom of my heart , but I cannot accept this sacrifice .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It is no sacrifice when I think that I can make you happy .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: But you mustn ’ t think of me . It ’ s your happiness that we have to consider . Don ’ t let a momentary impulse ruin your whole life .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ ve thought it over very carefully . I cannot resist your passionate pleading .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I will not be outdone in generosity . You have refused me . I accept your refusal as final .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I never realised that your nature was so great and tender . Every word you say makes me more determined to devote my life to your happiness .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: My dear Dot , much as I appreciate the beauty of your sentiments , I must confess that I could never marry a woman who did not love me .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: As though she were struggling with her modesty .I see that you want to force from me the avowal that is so hard to make . Oh , you men !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Good God , you don ’ t mean to say you ’ re in love with me ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Languishing .James . Is it so very wonderful ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Half an hour ago you said you couldn ’ t stand me at any price .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It ’ s a woman ’ s privilege to change her mind . The passion which you threw into your proposal has completely changed me . I am touched by the vehemence with which you flung your heart at my feet . I have struggled , but I cannot resist . Take me in your arms , James , and never let me go .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Dot , I have a confession to make to you . I didn ’ t mean a word I said .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Ah , James , do not jest .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I assure you I ’ m perfectly serious . You taunted me that I couldn ’ t make love , so I just let myself go to show you I could . I daresay it was a silly joke , but it certainly was a joke .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Unmoved .James , every word you say increases my admiration for you . I can ’ t think now how I was ever blind to your great affection .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: But don ’ t you hear what I say ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Do you think you can take me in so easily ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You don ’ t believe me ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Not a word .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Thoroughly alarmed .Now , look here . I don ’ t love you , I ’ ve never loved you , and I never shall love you . I can ’ t put it any clearer than that .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With rapture .God , how he adores me !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I say , look here , this is a bit too thick .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I know you only say these cruel things because you think I should be throwing myself away on you .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Huffily .I don ’ t know about that .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You cannot bear to think that I should accept you from pity . But it isn ’ t that , James . You are handsome and noble and chivalrous . How shouldn ’ t a woman love you ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I repeat that I do not reciprocate your passion .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You can ’ t deceive me so easily as that , James . I know you love me . We women have such quick intuitions .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: So you always say .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I see you simply quivering with restrained emotion . Oh , James , James , you ’ ve made me so happy .

div.stage: She flings herself on his bosom and pretends to burst into tears .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I say , take care . Supposing somebody saw us .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I should like all the world to see us .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: But it ’ s devilish compromising .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I want to compromise myself . Only thus can I make you certain of my love . Oh , think of the many happy years we shall spend in one another ’ s arms , James .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Extricating himself from her embrace .Is there nothing I can say to undeceive you ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Nothing ! I am yours till death .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: I will never give way to my sense of humour again .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Archly .Do you mind if I leave you just for one minute ? After so much agitation I must really go and powder my nose .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Ironically .Pray don ’ t let me detain you .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Remember I am yours till death .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: It is very good of you to say so .

div.stage: She goes out . He rings the bell impatiently . THE BUTLER comes in .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Tell my servant I want him .THE BUTLER goes out . BLENKINSOP walks up and down , wringing his hands . THE SERVANT enters .George , pack up my things at once and get the motor . There ’ s not a moment to lose .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Are you going away , sir ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Flying into a passion .You blithering fool , do you suppose I should want my things packed if I were staying ? I ’ m going abroad to-night .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Very well , sir .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: You must take the train and go to Cook ’ s at once and get some tickets .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Very well , sir . Where to , sir ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Don ’ t argue , sir , but do as I tell you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I must know where to get the tickets for , sir .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Oh , what it is to have a fool for a servant ! Take a month ’ s notice . I dismiss you . Where to , sir ? Anywhere , sir ? Somewhere that ’ s a damned long way off . South Africa ! I ’ ll go and shoot lions in Uganda . And if there isn ’ t a boat sailing at once , I ’ ll go to America and shoot grizzlies in the Rocky Mountains .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Very dangerous climate , sir .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Dangerous climate , sir ? I would have you know it ’ s not half such a dangerous climate as the valley of the Thames .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: He goes out . MRS . DOT comes in . At the sight of her BLENKINSOP at once cools down .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: James , dear , did I hear you give orders for your things to be packed up ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Calmly .No , my love . What could have put such an idea in your head ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: You wouldn ’ t leave me — darling ?

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: My angel , nothing now shall tear me from your side .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Dearest !

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: Trying to restrain himself .Pet !

div.stage: He goes into the garden . MRS . DOT begins to laugh . FREDDIE comes in , with letters in his hand .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I say , I wish you ’ d just have a look at these letters .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Oh , yes . I want to have a little talk with you , Freddie .She takes one of the letters and reads .“ I am directed by Mrs. Worthley to congratulate you on the recent addition to your family , but to express her regret that she cannot accede to your request .” How brutal you are , Freddie ! Surely Mrs. Murphy is an old friend .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I looked her out in my note-book . Six months ago we sent her fifteen pounds because she had nine children . Now she has eleven .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: And yet they complain that the birth-rate is falling . I think we ’ d better send her five pounds .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You really can ’ t encourage a woman who has twins twice a year , when her husband is not only bed-ridden but a hopeless lunatic .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Perhaps she is a little prolific .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Here is my answer to Mrs. MacTavish , who wants help to bury a husband .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Poor thing ! You ’ d better send her ten pounds .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ ve answered : “ Madam , I regret to see that this is the third time you have lost your husband within two years . The mortality among the unhappy gentlemen on whom you bestow your hand is so great that I can only recommend you in future to remain a widow . Yours faithfully , Frederick Perkins .”

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Reading a letter which he hands to her .“ I am pleased to hear that the wooden leg for which Mrs. Worthley paid for last year has proved satisfactory , but I cannot recommend her to provide you with another . To lose one leg in a railway accident is a misfortune , but to lose a second in a colliery explosion points to carelessness .” That ’ s not original , Freddie .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I ’ m so hard up , I can only afford to make other people ’ s jokes .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: With a shrewd look at him .Freddie , I ’ ve been exceedingly pleased with your behaviour during the last week . I ’ ve watched you carefully , and I ’ m glad to see that you ’ ve done all that was possible to destroy poor Nellie ’ s affection for you .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Gravely .I ’ ve tried to do my duty .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I know . And in recognition of this I want you to accept a little present . Where is my cheque-book ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Producing it promptly .Oh , no , really , I shouldn ’ t like you to do anything of the sort .Putting it in front of her , and giving her a pen .I feel that I ’ m amply paid for all that I do for you . I simply can ’ t accept anything more .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I was afraid you would object .

div.stage: She writes , and he watches her carefully .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Five hundred pounds . Oh , you are a ripper ! But why on earth do you give me that ?

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: It may be useful to you . Suppose you had an idea of getting married , for instance , it would be very convenient to have a sum like that in your pocket .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: But I ’ m not thinking of getting married .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Aren ’ t you ? I suppose you know that when you do , I ’ m proposing to give you two thousand a year .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I say , that ’ s awfully good of you .

div.stage: He takes the cheque and gloats over it . MRS . DOT quickly takes a special licence out of the drawer and puts it on the table .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Now I ’ m going for a turn in the garden .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You are a brick .

div.stage: She goes out . As soon as he sees the coast is clear , he gives a peculiar whistle . NELLIE comes in .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I thought your whistle was never coming . They wanted me to go on the river . I had to invent all sorts of excuses .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I don ’ t know how it is , but somehow we never manage to get a minute by ourselves .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: It ’ s perfectly maddening . What a good idea it was of yours to meet in the garden after they ’ d all gone to bed .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Was it my idea ? I always thought it was yours !

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: With wounded dignity .It ’ s not likely I should have proposed a thing like that .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: No , it isn ’ t likely .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I ’ m perfectly distracted . If you only knew how that man bores me !

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I can ’ t think what you ever saw in him .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I was never really fond of him , you know . I only accepted him because he was so desperately in love with me , and mamma wouldn ’ t hear of it .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: When did you first know that you cared for me ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh , I don ’ t know . I think as soon as ever I found out you were in love with me .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Rather taken aback .Oh !

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: When did you begin to love me ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Well , you know , I was awfully flattered by your caring for me .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh !...There is a pause .I don ’ t think I quite understand .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Opening his arms .Darling !

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Cuddling in them .Oh , it makes me feel so delightfully wicked . I know I oughtn ’ t to let you kiss me . I know it ’ s treachery to poor Gerald .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: He isn ’ t worthy of you .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: He simply worships the ground I tread on . I am a perfect beast .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: We ’ re treating him shamefully .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I shall never forgive myself .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Poor Gerald .... He is an ass , isn ’ t he ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh , awful .

div.stage: They both go into shrieks of laughter .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Take care !

div.stage: MRS . DOT comes in with flowers in her hands .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Did I leave my scissors here ? Just see if you can find them , Freddie . Perhaps they ’ re in the next room .He goes out .I wonder if I left them on the writing-table .

div.stage: NELLIE looks , sees the licence , starts , and turns round to hide it .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Agitated .No , there ’ s nothing here at all .

div.stage: FREDDIE comes in with the scissors .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Here they are !

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Thanks so much .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Freddie , how could you be so incautious ? It was only by the greatest presence of mind that I was able to hide it .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: You ought to have told me . I don ’ t think it was nice of you to get a licence without saying a word to me about it . I think it was a great liberty .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: A licence ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: You must know that I can ’ t marry you . Nothing will induce me to break my promise to Gerald . I ’ m very angry with you .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: I haven ’ t the least idea what you ’ re talking about .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: How can you tell such stories ?

div.stage: She hands him the licence . He stares at it , utterly astonished .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Where did you find this ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: It was lying on the writing-table . I suppose you ’ re not going to deny all knowledge of it .He stares at it still .Freddie , how bold of you ! But you really couldn ’ t imagine for a moment that I ’ d consent to run away with you . Oh , Freddie , I ’ m so flattered . How you must love me !

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: To himself .Two thousand a year !He takes the cheque from his pocket and looks at it . Suddenly light dawns on him . He puts cheque and licence back into his pocket .It ’ s fairly clear that a licence couldn ’ t have got there by itself .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: What on earth made you think of sending for it ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Brazenly .I thought it was the only way to win you .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Have you had it long ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: It only arrived this morning . Look here , why shouldn ’ t we bolt ? You don ’ t care a straw for Gerald , and you do care for me .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: It would break his heart . I couldn ’ t , I couldn ’ t ! Besides , where are we to bolt to ? I daren ’ t . Mamma would never forgive me .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You see , with this we can be married anywhere . Let ’ s jump into the motor and go down to my father near Oxford . We shall arrive by dinner-time , and he ’ ll marry us to-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: You don ’ t mean to say your father ’ s in the Church ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Of course he ’ s in the Church . I was most careful in my choice of a parent .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Oh , how clever of you to have a father who ’ s a clergyman ! You think of everything , Freddie .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Look here , there ’ s not a minute to waste . Will you risk it ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: No , no , no ! Freddie , how can you ask me such a thing .... I ’ ll just go and put on my hat .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: You brick .

div.stage: She runs out . He walks up and down excitedly . The servants bring in the tea . NELLIE comes back with her hat on .

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Hurry up !

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: This is romance , isn ’ t it ?

div.stage: They go to the door that leads into the garden , hand in hand . They are confronted by LADY SELLENGER and GERALD , BLENKINSOP and MISS MACGREGOR .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Where are you going in such a hurry ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Promptly .We were just going to call you all in to tea .

div.stage: MRS . DOT comes in .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I ’ ve just had the motor brought round in case any one would like to go out .

div.stage: She goes to the writing-table to see if the licence has been removed . They all sit down and have tea .

lg.l: Nellie , my love , I ’ ve been discussing a very important matter with
Gerald .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: I know . You asked him to name the day .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I feel that I have no right to restrain any longer the very natural impatience of these young things .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Aghast .And what did Gerald say ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: He wishes to leave it entirely to you .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I ’ m sure that ’ s very obliging of him .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: Of course , he ’ s all eagerness .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Grimly .Yes .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: I would much sooner — let Gerald fix it at his own convenience .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: I think it ’ s delightful , the way they give in to one another .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: We shall only bore Mrs . Dot if we discuss the matter now .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: We ’ re all old friends here . I ’ m sure Mrs . Dot will help us with her advice .

sp.speaker: MRS . DOT
sp.p: My own opinion is , that in these matters the sooner the better .

sp.speaker: BLENKINSOP
sp.p: When you have to take a pill the best thing is to swallow it down without thinking .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Cynic ! What do you say to six weeks from to-day ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: That would suit me beautifully .

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: Then there ’ s no more to be said .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: What a beautiful thing love is !

div.stage: NELLIE gets up .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: To FREDDIE .Are you coming ?

sp.speaker: FREDDIE
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Surprised .Where are you going , Nellie ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Mr. Perkins has promised to take me for a little drive in the motor . I feel it ’ s the only thing to send away my headache .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: In an undertone .My darling , is this wise ? Remember the feelings of this poor young man .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Also in an undertone .I thought you ’ d like an opportunity of talking privately to Gerald .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Why , darling ?

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Dear mamma , the settlements .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Smiling affectionately .You sweet , practical child ! You ’ ll be your own mother again at my age .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: May I go then ?

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: Do . But don ’ t be away very long .

sp.speaker: NELLIE
sp.p: Kissing her .Good-bye , mamma .

div.stage: She goes out with FREDDIE . Almost immediately the sound of a motor-horn is heard , as they drive away .

sp.speaker: LADY SELLENGER
sp.p: The dear child , she has such a sweet , trusting nature . You must kiss me , too , Gerald !

sp.speaker: GERALD
sp.p: I shall be delighted , I ’ m sure .

div.stage: She puts up her cheek , which he kisses . A SERVANT comes in with a
